ai-snp3.3:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-snp3.3:1.3_0: There the Fortunate One addressed the monks, (saying):
ai-snp3.3:2.1_0: “Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.
ai-snp3.3:2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; they speak on the teaching, not against the teaching; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely.
ai-snp3.3:2.4_0: Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”
ai-snp3.3:2.5_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-snp3.3:2.6_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-snp3.3:3.1_0: “Good people say that well-spoken words are foremost;
ai-snp3.3:3.2_0: second, speak on the teaching, not against it;
ai-snp3.3:3.4_0: and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”
ai-snp3.3:4.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-snp3.3:4.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-snp3.3:4.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-snp3.3:4.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-snp3.3:5.4_0: such speech is truly well spoken.
ai-snp3.3:6.3_0: or to reach the end of suffering,
ai-snp3.3:6.4_0: that bring nothing bad to others.
ai-snp3.3:7.1_0: Truth itself is the undying word:
ai-snp3.3:7.3_0: Good people say that the teaching and its meaning
ai-snp3.3:8.1_0: The words spoken by the Buddha
ai-snp3.3:8.3_0: for making an end of suffering:
ai-snp3.3:8.4_0: this really is the best kind of speech.”
